I like this epistemic responsibility idea, but I take a much weaker position on it. I think you have a responsibility not to act on or disclose a wrong belief without also disclosing the observations that make it wrong*, allowing you to consider any idea you want privately or discuss it in the proper context. I also think "without proof" is too strong; rather, I would define a "wrong belief" as an idea with *proof against it .

In other words, it is wrong to share an idea without disclosing any and all proof to the contrary . This would solve so many contemporary problems without drawing a lot of unnecessary controversy about God. We can't prove that God is not real; that's a belief for which there is no proof just as much as the opposite, so if we ban God, then we must also ban atheism. Many typical religious beliefs, however, would become immoral as individual ideas. That's "the earth is 8000 years old", "pi is exactly 3", "Jesus rode around on a dinosaur" and the like.

The weakness of this position is revealed in ideas like faith healing, or even the principle that God alone will decide whether you get COVID regardless of the precautions you take. One problem this episode doesn't grapple with, which I think is at the center of many conspiracy theories and the inability of laypeople to debunk them with evidence, is that in our modern world we have access to so much information that we can't possibly sort through it all. That's why the biggest experts are specialized, because in order to understand any issue both deeply and with a broad view of all the evidence takes most of a person's studying life.

This puts us in a predicament with this "epistemic responsibility" because it means that we don't have time to become experts in most of the things that we consider and about which we must decide. Many conspiracy theories have lots of evidence. Wrong conspiracy theories misinterpret the implications of the evidence, accept poorly generated and vetted evidence, and usually dismiss counter evidence as a smokescreen while assuming that partial evidence is only partial because they are clues that miraculously got through the veil of secrecy. But to prove that they are wrong, one must evaluate the hundreds of pieces of evidence, each of which requires understanding surrounding contextual facts in order to evaluate them. Not only don't we have the time to disprove all of these theories, we don't have the time to prove almost any of the beliefs that most people hold.

Instead of doing that research we are forced to rely either on lay consensus or expert consensus, assuming that the objections to the accepted view of reality have been responsibly vetted by more educated people. This includes almost all of our knowledge--I've never seen an atom, someone walking on the moon, anything that happened in history, etc. In fact, there are very few things that we know about through direct and thorough experience and research.

"Hard determinists" believe that if reliable cause and effect is universal, then free will must not exist. Is this a belief for which there is any clear evidence? Well, no. Free will is when we decide for ourselves what we will do, free of coercion or other undue influence. Since reliable cause and effect is a rather mundane presumption that we all make, it is neither coercive nor undue. For example, if you ask someone, "Why did you choose A rather than B?", she will happily give you her reasons why A was the better choice. In other words, her own reasons caused her choice, and she knows it. So the idea that free will implies the lack of reliable cause and effect is false, based upon the evidence.

Where then did the "hard determinists" get the idea that free will required "freedom from reliable cause and effect". Well, it's called a "reification fallacy". That's when we get caught up in our metaphors to the extent that we start confusing concepts with actual things that exist. The "hard determinist" claims that causation is causing everything so we must not be causing anything. But causation is simply a concept we use to describe the reliable interaction of objects and forces as they bring about events. Rather than saying, "this object did that, which caused this other object to do this", they summarize it to "causation" being the cause.

It seems like an innocent error, until they start claiming that "we" don't cause anything, but are only caused to do stuff by "prior causes". But the empirical fact is that we are real objects that exist in the universe, and we also happen to be living organisms that act purposefully to survive, thrive, and reproduce, and we also happen to be an intelligent species that can imagine more than one way to achieve our purpose, estimate how things will turn out if we choose this instead of that, and finally choose what we will do, according to our own purpose and our own reasons.

Two facts then are simultaneously true:
A) Because we made our choice according to our own purpose and our own reasons, without coercion or undue influence, this is authentically free will.
B) Because we made our choice according to our own purpose and our own reasons, without coercion or undue influence, this is authentically deterministic.

Thus, the hard determinist's claim that determinism is incompatible with free will is proven to be false.

An explanation of why belief in any god is a forced option:

The first thing which must be understood is difference between gnosticism (not the Christian sect, but the philosophical term) and theism, as they are two different questions. The question of whether you are theistic or atheistic is the question of "Do you believe in a god or do you not?" On the other hand, the question of gnosticism or agnosticism is the question of "Do you know a god exists or do you not?"

Agnosticism is not a middle ground between theism and atheism, rather, it is a feature of one's theism or atheism, as it can be appended to either. The agnostic atheist is the most common version: this is the group which most often calls themselves agnostic. They do not hold an active belief in any particular god, but they do not claim to know for certain that no god exists. On the other hand, an agnostic theist is someone who does believe in one or more gods but who also does not claim any certain knowledge of their existence. Continuing on, there are gnostic theists and gnostic atheists. The former are often called fundamentalists. They believe in one or more gods and they claim to know for certain that their god(s) absolutely do(es) exist(s). The gnostic atheist, often called an antitheist, does not hold any belief in any god, and moreover actively believes that no gods exist.

So you see, we are working with two different true dichotomy which form 4 distinct groups of people when taken together. The question of theism (belief in one or more gods): do you believe or do you not -- and the question of gnosticism (certain knowledge of the existence of any god): do you know that any god exists or do you not?

Arguing that you are morally sinful for holding a belief with insufficient evidence is simply not possible. The entire point of intelligence is the ability to solve unfamiliar problems with insufficient data. Human brains are pretty good at recognising patterns and so deducing the way the nature works, but it usually takes many wrong guesses at fictitious patterns before a correct one is found. Often not even that. Look at stuff like quantum physics - all we have at present are best guesses. Far as I'm concerned, the entire field's existence is a best guess, but it seems to work up to a point.

Holding a belief with insufficient evidence is how intelligence works. The more "intelligent" a creature is, the more likely it is to hold onto the correct beliefs. To refuse to act unless absolute, perfect certainty exists brings us all the way back to René Descartes - absolute certainly doesn't exist. Sooner or later we need to accept some things to be true or else we can't function. I don't need to understand fluid dynamics in order to hold the belief that my car's brakes will work when I stamp on the pedal, even though my life depends on it and it could very easily not be true some of the time. We work with what we have, or we don't work at all.

Inversely, though - arguing that a "live forced momentous" belief is OK to hold without evidence seems the most backwards to me. Ultimately, we work with what we have. Sometimes - a lot of times - we make uninformed decisions either because being informed is literally impossible or else because it's not practical, or else still because it doesn't matter. Foundationless beliefs are indefensible, because, not only to do inform your decisions (and thus affect the world and the people around you), but they also introduce the possibility of confirmation bias. By holding an opinion, that colours your view of new evidence, and if you hold a false opinion (which a baseless opinion may well be) then that bias is only going to force you further and further from the truth.

Therefore, holding a foundationless belief is an choice to understand the world less well. By holding a belief for which you have no evidence, you are choosing to drift further and further from actual knowledge. It is wilful and persistent and growing ignorance.

The (fairly common) idea that it's okay to believe in an unsubstantiated belief so long as it doesn't obligate any action on the part of the person who believes it is, I think, untrue. And this is simply because while a belief may not force you to take action (or not take action) right now, it may do so in the future and you can't possibly say for certain that it won't.

A good example of this is the notion that death is a good thing, or at least that death is not a bad thing. One can see this in almost much every religion on the face of the planet. Finding a religion which doesn't say that there is life after death, or that death is necessary and good, is hard (though not impossible, I know of at least one).

Turn the clock back a few hundred years and one could say "Why does it matter if you believe death is a bad thing or not? It's not like we could do anything about it if it was, so there's no possible moral cost in that belief." Except nowadays, while anti-aging treatments and more exotic forms of immortality are still a far-off dream, they're something we can be certain are within the realm of possible technologies.

So all of a sudden, those unsubstantiated beliefs about death matter. A lot. Someone who believes that they'll go to heaven when they die may choose (eventual) death over immortality. Whether such technological endeavors are funded may rest on such beliefs. And one day if those technologies become a reality, people may be faced with a choice to live forever or die, and make that decision based on unsubstantiated beliefs. Unsubstantiated beliefs spread and encouraged back in a day when the thought of human-wrought immortality wasn't even a remote possibility.

You just don't know what the future holds. And unless you do, there is no way to guarantee an unsubstantiated belief won't have any impact.

While I don't agree with William James' views on God, he is right, I feel, in regards to agnosticism. What most people don't understand is that atheism, agnosticism and theism do not sit on a scale, they do not fade seamlessly into each other. Agnosticism and gnosticism revolve around purporting to have knowledge, while theism and atheism revolve around belief.

If you are an agnostic, you do not claim to have knowledge over the existence of God; if you are a gnostic, you DO claim to have knowledge over the existence of God. If you are an atheist, you do not have a belief in a god or gods. If you are a theist, you have a belief in a god or gods. A belief is a conviction, so if you lack a conviction in God's existence, you do not believe in God: you are an atheist. One or the other, nothing in between.

Thus we get a Punnet square with atheism and theism at the top and agnosticism and gnosticism along the side: you can believe in God and claim to know there is one, a gnostic theist; you can lack belief in God and claim no knowledge of his existence, an agnostic theist. These two being the most common combinations. So when asked if one BELIEVES in God, saying you don't know whether there is one, or you are an agnostic, is not an answer. If you lack conviction there is one, you are an atheist. No middle ground, no grey area.

However, the problem of what we mean by knowledge comes up: without sufficient evidence for the existence of God, or fairies, or Santa, we might say we have no conviction or belief, but does this lack of evidence mean we know there is no God or fairies or Santa? Of course, we can know inductively, without 100% certainty, we do this all the time, it does not mean we lack any certainty, but we rarely base our beliefs on lack of evidence. All our inductive reasoning is based on observation, experimentation, so we can rule out some hypotheses and substantiate another. The fact that no sufficient scientific evidence exists for something means we can be fairly certain it does not exists, but knowledge is rarely based on lack of evidence. True, we may have no reason to believe in fairies, does that mean we KNOW no fairies exist?
